In the circuit of <image 1>. Find $v_C(t)$ for t > 0.

A. [70.7 cos (20t - 60^{\circ})] u(t) V
B. [70.7 cos (10t - 45^{\circ})] u(t) V
C. [70.7 cos (20t - 45^{\circ})] u(t) V
D. [70.7 cos (20t - 90^{\circ})] u(t) V

To find \(v_C(t)\) for \(t > 0\), we need to analyze the circuit in Fig. 1. The circuit consists of a voltage source \(50V\) and a current source \(5A\) in series with a inductor \(L = \frac{1}{2H}\) and a capacitor \(C = 0.005\,F\).

The voltage across the inductor \(v_L(t)\) is given by:
\[v_L(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ})\]

The voltage across the capacitor \(v_C(t)\) is given by:
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]

Since the current source \(I_L(t) = 5A\) is in series with the inductor, the current through the inductor is \(I_L(t)\). The voltage across the inductor is the current times the resistance of the inductor, which is \(50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ})\). The voltage across the capacitor is the current times the capacitance, which is \(50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\).

The voltage across the capacitor is the voltage across the inductor plus the voltage across the capacitor, which is:
\[v_C(t) = v_L(t) + v_C(t)\]

Substituting the expressions for \(v_L(t)\) and \(v_C(t)\) into this equation, we get:
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]

Using the trigonometric identity \(\cos(A - B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B\), we can simplify this expression:
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
\[v_C(t) = 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 60^{\circ}) + 50V \cdot \cos(20t - 45^{\circ})\]
